awd_titl_txt: CIF/AF: Small: Some fundamental complexity-inspired coding theory challenges
awd_abstract_narration:
Error-correcting codes provide a judicious way to add redundancy to data in order to safeguard its utility even when corrupted by various forms of errors. Codes are crucial to the reliable communication and storage of data, and find widespread use in diverse applications. This project is aimed at tackling a collection of fundamental challenges concerning various aspects of error-correcting codes. The questions underlying the project are inspired and technically integrated by the PI?s ongoing work in complexity theory and algorithmic coding theory. Progress on these questions will improve our understanding of the power and limitations of error-correcting codes in several models, as well as strengthen the connections between coding theory and various other fields such as information theory, combinatorics, pseudorandomness, cryptography, graph theory, and complexity theory.

The project will study the performance of error-correcting codes in many settings, such as communication on discrete memoryless channels with a specific focus on convergence to Shannon capacity of polar codes; codes resilient against worst-case deletions; local testability and decodability; non-malleability against natural tampering attacks, etc.  The discovery of new coding schemes has potential applications in data storage and communication. Non-malleable coding schemes can serve as building blocks for tamper-resilient cryptography. Locally decodable codes can improve the efficiency of distributed storage applications leading to substantial cost savings. The research will employ ideas from computer science in setting new directions for research in coding theory, thereby enhancing the connection between the computer science and information theory communities. On the education front, the project will engage several graduate students and provide a stimulating research environment for them, and help with the planned writing of a textbook on essential coding theory.

por.por_cntn:
Error-correcting codes safeguard data from the adverse effects of noise during data storage, retrieval, or communication, by judiciously introducing redundancy that enables removal of the errors inflicted by the noise model. Codes are indispensable tools at the core of the digital information age, and their importance has never been greater given the ever-increasing amounts of data generated, stored and communicated in today's cloud based information processing environment.

The subject of error-correcting codes dates back to the seminal works of Shannon and Hamming in 1948, and has made great strides since. Much of the classical progress was made by electrical engineers and information theorists, on both the theoretical and practical aspects, ushering in widespread adoption of codes in digital communications and storage. In the last 2-3 decades, renewed progress has been made in the constructions and algorithms for error-correction based on insights from computer science. This project investigated several questions at the frontiers of error-correction in various models, based in part on inspiration and techniques from computational complexity, a thriving topic in theoretical computer science.

The project obtained several results on polar codes, a remarkable discovery from about a decade ago, which achieve optimal information transmission rates approaching a fundamental limit (called Shannon capacity) of probabilistic channels. The research developed general analysis methods for polar codes, which established fast convergence of the information rate to capacity, realizing a long sought-after constructive version of Shannon's seminal noisy coding theorem matching its quantitatively strong parameters. The project rekindled a substantial study of codes against synchronization errors such as insertions and deletions, a noise model that has traditionally been very hard to cope with and which did not witness much progress despite early work in the 1960s. List error-correction, a notion that enables tackling a much larger fraction of errors than traditional methods by allowing the decoder to output a small number of candidate codewords in the worst-case, was a continuing focus and led to many results.  Codes with highly efficient local recovery algorithms, that are of great importance to distributed storage systems, were investigated from various angles. The project led both to novel code constructions as well as results on inherent limitations of codes in all these models. Novel connections to cryptographic notions such as secret sharing and non-malleability amplified the impact of the work beyond coding theory.  

Overall, the project greatly improved our understanding of the power and limitations of error-correcting codes in several models, and strengthened the connections between coding theory and various other fields such as information theory, combinatorics, pseudorandomness, cryptography, graph theory, and computational complexity.

For broader impact, the research and outreach activities associated with the project enhanced the cross-fertilization of ideas between information theorists and computer scientists on various aspects related to error-correction. Despite overlapping motivation, goals and interests, these communities have largely progressed via somewhat different methods with little interaction. Various synergistic activities such as workshop and semester program organization, and continued writing of a textbook on essential coding theory, also accompanied the research goals of the project. The project trained and mentored several graduate students, provided a stimulating research environment for them, and led to multiple high quality Ph.D. dissertations, thereby paving a career path for the students in research and education. The project also formed the basis of some highly successful undergraduate research experiences, leading to publications by undergraduates at the most selective venues of the field and placing them in top Ph.D. programs.
